== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings =
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===
== Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Jordan was born on April 7, 1992, in Columbia, South Carolina, to a mother of African American, white, Native American descent and a Puerto Rican father.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Jordan began writing songs while she was in third grade.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: At the age of 11, she moved with her parents and three younger siblings Taylor, Malichai and Malcolm to Santa Clarita, California, to pursue a career in the arts.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: At the age of 12, Jordan served as an opening act for Smokey Robinson at a Stevie Wonder tribute concert.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: In 2006, Jordan auditioned for the first season of America's Got Talent.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: She sang Whitney Houston's "I Have Nothing" at her audition and made it through to the next round, only to be eliminated in the semifinals.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Judge Brandy brought her back to compete in the semifinals, after the public didn't gather enough votes for Jordan.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: After being eliminated from the show, Jordan and her family moved to Atlanta to be closer to the music industry.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: While there, she began to upload cover songs on YouTube while submitting demos.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: By 2008, Jordan's YouTube page was racking up millions of views.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: The exposure led Jordan to the attention of production team Stargate who called her to fly to New York and record a few songs with them.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: While in the studio, rapper Jay-Z walked in, which ultimately resulted in Jordan becoming the first artist signed to the new, Sony Music-affiliated label, StarRoc/Roc Nation – a joint venture between Stargate and Jay-Z's Roc Nation label.
section: == Life and career == | === 1992–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Her self-titled debut album was released on February 25, 2011.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: The album was recorded from January 1, 2007, to October 15, 2010, in which Jordan worked with StarGate, Sandy Vee, Nightwatch and Espionage.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: The album debuted at number twenty-eight in Ireland on March 4, 2011.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: In the United Kingdom, the album debuted at number nine on March 6, 2011.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: The album also debuted at number eleven in Australia.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: On April 30, 2011, the album debuted at number 80 on the Dutch Album Chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: In its 13th week the album shot from 72 to 23, reaching its peak of 21 two weeks later.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: Jordan's single "Happiness" was released in September 2010.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: In the United States, the song reached No. 1 on the Hot Dance Club Songs, becoming Jordan's first No. 1 single on that chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: It also reached No. 1 in Norway and the Netherlands (where it stayed for 10 weeks), and peaked at No. 3 in Australia and the United Kingdom.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: In Australia, "Happiness" was certified triple platinum by the Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA), for shipments of 210,000 copies.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: "Good Girl" was released as Jordan's second single in February 2011.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: The song debuted at No. 6 on the UK Singles Chart, giving Jordan her second top-10 hit in the United Kingdom.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: It also reached No. 15 in Ireland and became her second chart-topper on the Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs chart in April.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: "Hush Hush" was released as the album's third single on May 8, 2011.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: On April 12, 2012 Alexis embarked on her first headline tour in the United Kingdom.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: Jordan performed in three cities – London (Scala) on Thursday June 30, Birmingham HMV (Institute) on Saturday July 2 and Manchester (Club Academy) on Sunday July 3.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: Tickets went on sale on Friday April 15.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: In June and July 2011 Jordan also supported British boy band JLS on their eight-day UK tour.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: She also appeared at T4 on the Beach in the UK and performed "Hush Hush" and "Good Girl".
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: Jordan featured on Sean Paul's single "Got 2 Luv U", which reached number one in Switzerland, Netherlands, Norway, Bulgaria, Romania, France,  United States Billboard (in the Latin Raps & Pop Songs) and Venezuela.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: Jordan also made a cameo appearance in the film Honey 2.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–12: Record deal and Alexis Jordan ===

sentences: In June 2012 Jordan performed at Birmingham Pride performing "Good Girl", "Got 2 Luv U", "Shout Shout", "Hush Hush" On November 25, 2012, she appeared as musical guest on X Factor (Romania).

sentences: Second studio album ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: In October 2011, she confirmed via Twitter that she was working on her second studio album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: In November 2011, Jordan went to a recording studio in New York where she recorded with Stargate, she stated that the album is nearly completed.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: In the same YouTube video uploaded by Jordan, she was asked what she was doing and she replied "Writing about different things 'cause I'm like all messed up cause I'm talking about girl power, then I'm talking about myself and how people don't really know me that well so they gonna get to know me in this song.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: "On January 15, 2013, a new song titled "Acid Rain" leaked online.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: It was intended to serve as the lead cut from her second album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: "Acid Rain" samples Bingo Players‘ song “Rattle,” and is written by Sia Furler and produced by Stargate.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: However it served only as a buzz single, as it was leaked in early 2013 and was never released on worldwide radios.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: On December 28, 2013 Jordan released a new message on her Facebook page in which she confirms that the official lead single from her then upcoming second studio album would be titled "Gone" and it would be released on March 1, 2014.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: The official video was shot in late 2013.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: Its official music video was premiered on February 28, 2014.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: Jordan was dropped by Jay-Z's Roc Nation label after the single failed to chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012–14: Second studio album ===

sentences: Jordan's self-titled debut album contained dance-pop, pop and R&B music, in an interview Jordan described the album's musical style saying "I don’t want to be kept in a box.

sentences: I’m that pop artist, but I can switch it up and turn to R&B/soul and do lots of ballads and the hip-hop swag.
section: == Artistry == | === Music and influences ===

sentences: It’s very versatile".
section: == Artistry == | === Music and influences ===

sentences: Alexis described her album's genre as being "universal" saying in an interview "It's going to be very universal.
section: == Artistry == | === Music and influences ===

sentences: It's not just a pop dance record.
section: == Artistry == | === Music and influences ===

sentences: It has a little reggae, a little hip-hop swag, so it's going to be everything.
section: == Artistry == | === Music and influences ===

sentences: "Jordan cites singers Christina Aguilera, Whitney Houston, Mariah Carey and Beyoncé as influences.

sentences: Jordan also cites Michael Jackson as an influence calling him "a big inspiration" and also is inspired by Billie Holiday saying "I like Billie Holiday’s sound".
